docs.lead_paragraph: In ruling for free coverage for women, the administration rejected a broad exemption for employees of Roman Catholic hospitals, colleges and charities.

headline.seo: Administration Rules Insurers Must Cover Contraceptives
headline.main: Obama Reaffirms Insurers Must Cover Contraception
headline.print_headline: U.S. Denies Exemption Sought by Church on Coverage for Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Obama administration says that most health insurance plans must cover contraceptives for women free of charge and rejects a broad exemption by the Roman Catholic Church for insurance provided to employees of Catholic hospitals, colleges and charities.
docs.snippet: In ruling for free coverage for women, the administration rejected a broad exemption for employees of Roman Catholic hospitals, colleges and charities.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Laurie Goodstein contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug being tested on dachshunds and other dogs with spinal cord damage may eventually lead to new treatments for people with similar injuries.
docs.abstract: An experimental drug being tested on dachshunds and other dogs with spinal cord damage may eventually lead to new treatments for people with similar injuries.
docs.snippet: An experimental drug being tested on dachshunds and other dogs with spinal cord damage may eventually lead to new treatments for people with similar injuries.

docs.lead_paragraph: To head off medical conflicts of interest, the companies would be required to disclose what they pay doctors for research, consulting, speaking, travel and entertainment.

headline.seo: U.S. to Tell Drug Makers to Disclose Payments to Doctors
headline.main: U.S. to Force Drug Firms to Report Money Paid to Doctors
headline.print_headline: Fees To Doctors By Drugs Makers To Be Disclosed

docs.abstract: Obama administration is poised to require drug companies to disclose the payments they make to doctors for research, consulting, speaking, travel and entertainment, in an effort to head off medical conflicts of interest; many researchers have found evidence that such payments can influence doctors’ treatment decisions and contribute to higher costs by encouraging the use of more expensive drugs and medical devices.
docs.snippet: To head off medical conflicts of interest, the companies would be required to disclose what they pay doctors for research, consulting, speaking, travel and entertainment.
